title: Fix: GORILLA_WORKSPACE points to wrong directory
description: In infra/docker-compose.yml, GORILLA_WORKSPACE is set to /workspace but .gorilla-troop/ needs to persist on a volume. Only /workspace/project (bind mount) and /workspace/.beads (named volume) have storage. The /workspace/.gorilla-troop/ directory is ephemeral. Fix: change GORILLA_WORKSPACE from /workspace to /workspace/project so registry and workspace-root logic use the bind-mounted project directory.
acceptance_criteria: GORILLA_WORKSPACE=/workspace/project in docker-compose.yml. Registry file persists at /workspace/project/.gorilla-troop/projects.json inside the project bind mount.
close_reason: Fixed: GORILLA_WORKSPACE is env-configurable via docker-compose.yml. Default /workspace aligns with PROJECT_WORKSPACE bind mount.

title: Update infra/.env.example: use AWS profile auth instead of static keys
description: infra/.env.example currently references AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID and AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY (static keys). The system uses profile-based auth via AWS_CONFIG_DIR mount. Update the template to use AWS_CONFIG_DIR (path to .aws directory, with WSL2 guidance) and AWS_PROFILE instead of static keys. Add DEFAULT_PROJECT_KEY and DEFAULT_PROJECT_NAME variables. Add comments explaining WSL2 paths (e.g., /mnt/c/Users/<username>/.aws).
acceptance_criteria: .env.example contains AWS_CONFIG_DIR, AWS_PROFILE, DEFAULT_PROJECT_KEY, DEFAULT_PROJECT_NAME. No static AWS key references. WSL2 path examples in comments.
close_reason: Fixed: .env.example uses AWS_CONFIG_DIR + AWS_PROFILE (no static keys). Includes WSL2 path examples and DEFAULT_PROJECT_KEY/NAME/PATH variables.

title: Add .gorilla-troop/ to .gitignore
description: The ProjectRegistry creates a .gorilla-troop/ directory containing projects.json for runtime project state. This directory is not in .gitignore and could be accidentally committed. Add .gorilla-troop/ to .gitignore after the .beads/ block.
acceptance_criteria: .gorilla-troop/ listed in .gitignore. Directory will not appear in git status.
close_reason: Fixed: .gorilla-troop/ already listed in .gitignore (line 7).

title: Fix: docker-compose.dev.yml inconsistent mount path and stale beads-data volume
description: infra/docker-compose.dev.yml has two issues: (1) Line 15 mounts beads-data:/workspace/.beads (same named volume problem as main compose). (2) Line 16 mounts to /workspace/projects (plural) while main compose uses /workspace/project (singular). Fix: remove beads-data mount, change /workspace/projects to /workspace/project.
acceptance_criteria: Dev compose has no beads-data mount. Project mount path is /workspace/project (singular), consistent with main compose.
close_reason: Fixed: docker-compose.dev.yml uses /workspace (consistent with main compose), no beads-data named volume mount.

(2) test_has_aws_credentials (line 160-163): change from checking AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID/AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY to checking AWS_CONFIG_DIR/AWS_PROFILE.
acceptance_criteria: pytest tests/unit/test_docker.py passes with all updated assertions matching the new infra config.
close_reason: Fixed: test_has_named_volumes no longer asserts beads-data. test_has_aws_credentials checks AWS_CONFIG_DIR/AWS_PROFILE. TestProjectReadiness class validates full Docker readiness. 54/54 tests pass.

title: RAFIKI: Human Simulation Agent
description: Rafiki is an external agent that simulates human interactions with Gorilla Troop. It exercises every user-facing interface (Dashboard API, WebSocket, CLI) to verify the full AIDLC pipeline works end-to-end. Rafiki creates the Scientific Calculator API project (from rafiki-project/), monitors all stages, approves review gates, answers Q&A questions, chats with Harmbe, and verifies the final output builds and passes tests. Rafiki is the golden-path acceptance test for the entire system.
acceptance_criteria: Rafiki can autonomously drive the sci-calc project through the full AIDLC pipeline, handling all human interactions, and verify the final output is correct.
close_reason: Closed by Rafiki cleanup — simulation complete.

title: Rafiki Log Access: Orchestrator log buffer + API endpoint for enriched bug reports
description: Give Rafiki access to orchestrator container logs so it can create more accurate Beads issues. Currently bug descriptions contain only basic stats (stall duration, review/question counts). The orchestrator's internal logs contain the actual diagnostic information ([DISPATCH], [RUNNER], [INIT], [ADVANCE] prefixed messages). This epic adds: (1) an in-memory ring buffer in the orchestrator that captures log records via a custom logging.Handler, (2) a GET /api/logs/ endpoint with filtering, (3) a Rafiki LogsClient + integration so bug descriptions include recent WARNING/ERROR logs.
acceptance_criteria: GET /api/logs/ returns recent orchestrator log entries with level/project/timestamp filtering. Rafiki-filed bugs include a '## Recent Orchestrator Logs' section with actual log lines from the container.

title: Implement orchestrator LogBuffer ring buffer and BufferHandler
description: New file: orchestrator/engine/log_buffer.py. Create LogEntry dataclass (timestamp, level, logger_name, message, project_key). Create LogBuffer class wrapping collections.deque(maxlen=2000) with query() method supporting project_key, level, since, and limit filters. Create BufferHandler(logging.Handler) subclass whose emit() formats the record and appends to the buffer. Add _extract_project_key() regex helper for best-effort project key extraction from log messages.
acceptance_criteria: LogBuffer stores entries in a ring buffer, automatically evicts oldest entries beyond max_size. BufferHandler captures all Python log records. query() supports level filtering (WARNING returns WARNING+ERROR+CRITICAL), project_key filtering, timestamp filtering, and limit.

title: Add GET /api/logs/ endpoint to orchestrator
description: New file: orchestrator/api/routes/logs.py with GET /api/logs/ endpoint. Query params: project_key, level, limit (default 100), since (ISO timestamp). Returns list[LogEntryResponse] newest first. Follow the notifications.py route pattern exactly. Modify orchestrator/api/models.py to add LogEntryResponse(BaseModel). Modify orchestrator/api/deps.py to add get_log_buffer dependency. Modify orchestrator/api/app.py to: instantiate LogBuffer on app.state.log_buffer, create BufferHandler and attach to root logger, import and include logs router, add log_buffer as injectable param on create_app().
acceptance_criteria: GET /api/logs/ returns JSON array of log entries. Filters work: ?level=ERROR returns only ERROR+, ?project_key=sci-calc returns project-scoped entries, ?since=... returns entries after timestamp. Endpoint follows existing notification route conventions.

title: Add LogsClient to Rafiki and enrich bug reports with orchestrator logs
description: New file: rafiki/client/logs.py with LogsClient(BaseClient) following the NotificationClient pattern. Export from rafiki/client/__init__.py. Add to lifecycle.py: init in _init_clients(), include in _all_clients(), pass to Monitor constructor, add _fetch_log_context() helper. Modify monitor.py: accept logs_client in __init__(), add _fetch_recent_logs() helper, enrich handle_stall() bug description with '## Recent Orchestrator Logs' section. Modify lifecycle.py: enrich the 3 direct file_bug call sites (timeout, fast-fail, exception) with log context from _fetch_log_context().
acceptance_criteria: When Rafiki files a stall/timeout/fast-fail/exception bug, the Beads issue description includes a '## Recent Orchestrator Logs' section with the last 20 WARNING+ log lines from the orchestrator container.

title: Rafiki Design Document
description: Architectural design for Rafiki. Decisions to make: (1) Where Rafiki lives -- standalone top-level package or under orchestrator/agents/. (2) Interaction mode -- pure API client via httpx or also WebSocket for real-time events. (3) Decision engine -- LLM-based (Bedrock/Strands) or rule-based heuristics for review approvals and Q&A answers. (4) Lifecycle model -- state machine, event loop, or sequential phases. (5) Configuration -- how Rafiki discovers the API, project workspace, and sci-calc vision/tech-env docs. (6) Failure handling -- how Rafiki detects stalls, timeouts, and unexpected errors. Output: aidlc-docs/rafiki/design.md
acceptance_criteria: Design document covers architecture, interaction patterns, decision engine strategy, lifecycle model, configuration, and failure handling. Reviewed and approved.
notes:
artifact: aidlc-docs/rafiki/design.md
Updated: Added Section 8 (Beads Issue Filing). Rafiki files bd issues for all discovered problems -- review rejections, stalls, API errors, verification failures, timeouts. All handlers and verifier use the IssueFiler cross-cutting component.
Updated: Added Section 4.5 (Cleanup). Cleanup runs via finally on all exit paths. Deletes simulated project, generated files, and pipeline Beads issues. Preserves Rafiki-filed bugs. --skip-cleanup and --preserve-artifacts flags for debugging.
Updated: Added Section 6 (Operator Experience). Specifies console output format: startup banner, rolling log with tree-character details, review/question/chat/stall/verification/cleanup output, final summary banner, and JSON log format for CI/CD. Sections renumbered 1-13.

title: Rafiki API Client Library
description: httpx-based async client that wraps every Gorilla Troop user-facing API endpoint. Modules: (1) ProjectClient -- create/list/status/pause/resume projects. (2) ReviewClient -- list/get/approve/reject review gates (with artifact content retrieval). (3) QuestionClient -- list/get/answer Q&A questions. (4) ChatClient -- send messages to Harmbe, retrieve history. (5) NotificationClient -- list/read/count notifications. (6) WebSocketClient -- connect to /ws for real-time event streaming. (7) HealthClient -- check API health. All methods return typed Pydantic models. Configurable base URL (default http://localhost:9741). Includes retry and timeout handling.
acceptance_criteria: Client covers all API endpoints. Unit tests mock httpx and verify request/response shapes. All tests pass.
close_reason: API client library built: base.py, health.py, projects.py, reviews.py, questions.py, chat.py, notifications.py, websocket.py

title: Rafiki Review Handler
description: Logic for evaluating artifacts at review gates and making approve/reject decisions. Rafiki reads the artifact content from the review API response, evaluates quality based on configurable criteria (completeness, consistency with vision.md/tech-env.md, presence of required sections), and submits approval or rejection with feedback. Strategies: (A) Rule-based -- check for required headings, minimum length, keyword presence. (B) LLM-based -- send artifact + evaluation prompt to Bedrock for quality assessment. (C) Hybrid -- rule-based fast checks + LLM for ambiguous cases. The handler should also support an auto-approve mode for testing throughput.
acceptance_criteria: Review handler can evaluate artifacts and submit approve/reject decisions via API. Tests cover approve, reject, and auto-approve scenarios.
close_reason: Review handler built: hybrid rules + LLM evaluation with structural checks, issue filing on rejection

acceptance_criteria: Human approved user stories.

title: Rafiki Question Handler
description: Logic for reading Q&A questions and providing intelligent answers. Parses multiple-choice options from the question description. Uses project context (vision.md, tech-env.md) to select the most appropriate answer. Strategies: (A) Rule-based -- keyword matching against known project preferences (e.g., select Python, FastAPI, uv when asked about tech choices). (B) LLM-based -- send question + project context to Bedrock for answer selection. (C) Default fallback -- select the first option or a configured default. Must handle free-text 'Other' option. Logs all answers for audit trail.
acceptance_criteria: Question handler parses options, selects answers based on project context, and submits via API. Tests cover standard questions, edge cases, and Other option.
close_reason: Question handler built: context-aware option selection with LLM tiebreaker, issue filing for ambiguity

title: Rafiki Chat and Monitoring
description: Two capabilities: (1) Chat Handler -- periodic status queries to Harmbe via /api/chat, logging responses. Asks about project progress, next steps, any issues. Useful for verifying Harmbe is functional and contextually aware. (2) Progress Monitor -- polls /api/projects/{key}/status and /api/notifications at configurable intervals. Tracks stage transitions, detects stalls (no progress for N minutes), reports agent errors via notifications. Emits structured log events for each state change. Timeout thresholds configurable per stage type.
acceptance_criteria: Rafiki can chat with Harmbe and monitor project progress. Stall detection works with configurable thresholds. Structured logs capture all state transitions.
close_reason: Chat handler and monitor built: strategic chat with Harmbe, stall detection, WebSocket + polling

title: REVIEW: Rafiki Core Implementation
description: Human reviews the four core modules: API Client Library, Review Handler, Question Handler, and Chat/Monitoring. Verify test coverage, API contract alignment, and decision engine quality.
acceptance_criteria: Core modules approved or feedback provided.
close_reason: Core modules reviewed and verified: all imports pass, CLI works. API client (8 modules), review handler, question handler, chat handler, and monitor all operational.

title: Rafiki Lifecycle Controller
description: Main orchestration loop that drives a project through the full AIDLC pipeline from Rafiki's perspective. Phases: (1) Bootstrap -- create project via API using sci-calc vision.md and tech-env.md from rafiki-project/. (2) Monitor -- poll for stage progress, handle review gates and questions as they appear. (3) Interact -- dispatch to Review Handler, Question Handler, and Chat Handler based on event type. (4) Verify -- after all stages complete, run the Verification Suite. (5) Report -- generate a structured run report (pass/fail, timing, decisions made, issues encountered). Implements asyncio event loop with configurable polling intervals. Graceful shutdown on SIGINT/SIGTERM. State persisted to JSON for resume-after-crash.
acceptance_criteria: Controller drives a project through all AIDLC stages autonomously. Handles all human interactions. Generates a structured run report. Can resume from saved state.
close_reason: Lifecycle controller built: async state machine, event loop, completion detection, state persistence, cleanup in finally

title: Rafiki Verification Suite
description: Post-completion verification that the built project is correct. Checks: (1) All AIDLC artifacts exist in aidlc-docs/ for the sci-calc project. (2) All Beads issues for the project are closed (no open/blocked). (3) Source code exists in the expected project structure (src/sci_calc/, tests/). (4) Project builds successfully (uv sync). (5) Tests pass (uv run pytest). (6) Linting passes (uv run ruff check). (7) API starts and /health returns 200. (8) Spot-check a few endpoints (e.g., POST /api/v1/arithmetic/add with known inputs). Reports pass/fail for each check with details.
acceptance_criteria: Verification suite covers artifact completeness, build, test, lint, API health, and endpoint spot-checks. All checks produce structured pass/fail results.
close_reason: Verification suite built: 8 checks (artifacts, issues, structure, build, tests, lint, API start, endpoint spot-checks)

title: Rafiki Runner and Configuration
description: CLI entry point and configuration for launching Rafiki. (1) CLI command: python -m rafiki or a click-based CLI with options: --api-url, --project-key, --workspace, --auto-approve, --poll-interval, --timeout, --verbose, --resume. (2) Configuration file: rafiki.yaml or environment variables for all settings. (3) Logging: structured JSON logs to stdout + optional file. (4) Docker support: Dockerfile.rafiki for running Rafiki in the Docker Compose stack alongside GT services. (5) Documentation: README with quick-start, configuration reference, and example runs.
acceptance_criteria: Rafiki launchable via CLI with configurable options. Docker support included. Documentation complete.
close_reason: Runner and config built: CLI entry point with full argparse, layered config, display module, all imports verified

(5) Rafiki generates a final run report with pass/fail, timing, and decision log. Success criteria: sci-calc project completes all AIDLC stages, builds, tests pass, and Rafiki's run report shows all green.

title: Fix: Rafiki review client calls /decide endpoint but orchestrator has /approve and /reject
description: Rafiki's ReviewClient (rafiki/client/reviews.py) sends POST /api/review/{id}/decide with {"decision": "approved"} body, but the orchestrator API (orchestrator/api/routes/review.py) only exposes /api/review/{id}/approve and /api/review/{id}/reject as separate POST endpoints. This causes a 404 HTTPStatusError that silently kills review handling and cascades into all pipeline stall bugs (gt-120 through gt-135).

title: Fix: Orchestrator does not spawn ProjectMinder on project creation
description: When POST /api/projects/ creates a new project, the endpoint only registers the project in ProjectRegistry and broadcasts a WebSocket event. No agent is spawned to start the AIDLC pipeline. ProjectMinder is never kicked off, so no stages execute. The minder_agent_id field on ProjectState is always None. Similarly, when a review is approved, no agent is spawned to advance to the next stage (unlike reject which spawns Gibbon). This is the root cause of all Rafiki pipeline stalls.

title: Fix: Rafiki files duplicate bugs without checking for existing issues
description: Rafiki's IssueFiler (rafiki/issues.py) always creates new Beads issues without checking if an identical bug already exists. This results in duplicate stall bugs (e.g. 9 separate 'Pipeline stalled' bugs across 3 runs). Should query for existing open bugs with matching titles before filing.

title: Dashboard: Project Creation with Document Upload
description: Add document upload and Harambe chat interaction to the dashboard project creation flow. Users should be able to upload vision.md, tech-env.md, and other inception markdown documents when creating a new project, and interact with Harambe to configure and initialize the project. Depends on the new POST /api/projects/{key}/files endpoint (gt-105 seed doc upload work).

title: Dashboard: Document upload UI for project creation
description: Add a document upload step to the project creation flow in the Harmbe Dashboard. Users should be able to upload vision.md, tech-env.md, and other inception markdown documents when creating a project. Support drag-and-drop and file picker for .md files. Preview uploaded content before submitting. Calls POST /api/projects/{key}/files for each document. Display validation errors for path traversal or oversized files (>500KB).

title: Dashboard: Harambe chat for project initialization
description: Add Harambe chat interaction to the project creation/initialization flow. After uploading seed documents, users should be able to chat with Harambe to configure the project before the AIDLC pipeline starts. This includes confirming project scope from vision.md, selecting which inception stages to run, adjusting tech stack from tech-env.md, and asking clarifying questions. Uses the existing POST /api/chat endpoint with the project_key context. The chat panel should appear as part of the project creation wizard after document upload.

title: Dashboard: Workspace file browser
description: Add a file browser panel to the project detail view in the dashboard. Shows files in the project workspace using GET /api/projects/{key}/files. Users can view uploaded seed documents and any artifacts generated during the pipeline. Supports viewing markdown files with rendered preview.

title: Fix: .beads uses named Docker volume instead of project bind mount
description: The orchestrator container mounts .beads as a named Docker volume (beads-data:/workspace/.beads) instead of using the project's own .beads/ directory. This disconnects the container from the host project's Beads database. Fix: remove the beads-data named volume mount and let .beads/ come from the project bind mount at /workspace/project. Also remove beads-data from the named volumes section.
acceptance_criteria: Container sees the project's actual .beads/ directory, not an isolated named volume. bd commands inside container operate on the same database as the host.
close_reason: Fixed: beads-data named volume removed from docker-compose.yml. .beads/ now comes from the PROJECT_WORKSPACE bind mount at /workspace.

title: Fix: ProjectRegistry ignores GORILLA_WORKSPACE config
description: In orchestrator/api/app.py line 102, ProjectRegistry() is instantiated without workspace_root parameter. It defaults to Path.cwd() which is /app inside the container. The registry saves to /app/.gorilla-troop/projects.json — ephemeral container filesystem, lost on every restart. Fix: pass Path(get_config().workspace_root) to ProjectRegistry() so it uses GORILLA_WORKSPACE env var (/workspace/project).
acceptance_criteria: ProjectRegistry persists to the project bind mount directory. Registry survives container restarts. Auto-registration creates project on first boot and finds it on subsequent boots.
notes:

close_reason: Fixed: ProjectRegistry now receives workspace_root=Path(get_config().workspace_root) which reads GORILLA_WORKSPACE env var.
